title: Bug repelling technology could end to self-driving car malfunctions
text:
For humans, bugs are a pesky distraction, but for self-driving cars they can be a matter of life or death.

Ford, whose self-driving cars were just deployed in Austin, Texas, has come up with a novel set of tools to keep stray insects from interfering with the crucial sensors in its self-driving cars.

Developed in partnership with Argo AI, Ford's vehicles use a complex laser technology called Lidar to generate spatial information for the car's navigation system.

Ford, whose self-driving cars were just deployed in Austin, Texas, has come up with a novel set of tools to keep stray insects from interfering with the crucial sensors in its self-driving cars

Similar to a radar system, lidar sends out a laser light and measures small differences in the speed and angle of the light that's reflected back from the environment, as reported by VentureBeat

Those measurements are then used to generate information about surrounding vehicles and objects.

Predictably, the biggest challenge for the sensors aren't parked cars or irresponsible drivers but insects, which can end up smashed against the lidar sensors and throw off their readings.

A new story from Consumer Reports describes how Ford and Argo have devised a clever set of weapons to help keep the lidar system bug-free and the cars safely cruising on toward their destination.

It starts with the tiara, the name for the lidar housing that's mounted on the roof of the car.

Ford's vehicles use a complex laser technology called Lidar to generate spatial information for the car's navigation system. Part of the plan is a 16 spray nozzles that emit a soapy fluid across the lens housing to wash away anything that makes it through the air shield

WHAT IS LIDAR? Similar to RADAR Uses lasers instead of radio waves Reads light reflected by environment Most expensive system costs $75,000

The tiara's first line of defence is a small nozzle that shoots a constant stream of pressurized air across the sensor lens, ensuring that bugs and other road debris are pushed away before they get close.

There's also a system of 16 spray nozzles that emit a soapy fluid across the lens housing to wash away anything that makes it through the air shield.

'Our target is to have [the bug debris] cleaned in under one second,' Mark Bosca, Ford's chief engineer, tells Consumer Reports.

Lidar systems have been the source of some criticism in the self-driving car industry.

'Anyone relying on lidar is doomed,' Elon Musk said earlier this year, citing the technolgy's high cost as a reason it wouldn't be widely adopted.

The biggest name in the industry, Velodyne, sells there lidar sensors for $75,000, but a rival company, Luminar, has begun work on a competing version of the sensor that can be sold for $500.

Most of the semi-autonomous test programs currently on the road, including Tesla's Autopilot and Cadillac's Super Cruise, rely on radar sensors.
description: Bold new plan from Ford takes the transition from semi-autonomous to fully self-driving cars one step closer to reality. The technology uses pressurized air and spray nozzles to protect sensors.
